Award.AbstractNarration:
Ranging from the low-energy phenomena of cosmology to the highest energy of stellar jets, neutrinos are a fundamental ingredient of the universe that we observe, and offer unique windows into its mysteries. The purpose of this project is a theoretical study of these windows. Part of the research will be on neutrinos from core collapse supernovae: how these neutrinos are affected by flavor oscillations, and what their detection will teach us about the physics that takes place at extremely high density near the collapsed core. High-energy neutrino emission will also be investigated as a way to explore the physics of particle accelerators in our galaxy and beyond, with focus on propagation effects and detectability at present and future neutrino telescopes. Another area of study will be the physics of neutrinos in the early universe, how they connect to the nature of the dark matter, and how they can possibly reveal the existence of new particles and forces. This project will contribute to the ongoing transition to a new phase of neutrino physics, characterized by new, more powerful experiments and by a deeper understanding of the neutrino phenomenology.

Being based at a large public university, the project will benefit young scientists through educational activities and direct involvement in research. Specifically, the grant will support a postdoc and a graduate student, thus offering them an opportunity to enter the field, and join a new generation of neutrino physicists that will sustain the new phase of discoveries ahead.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This a project in theoretical physics, centered on the properties of the most elusive of elementary particles, the neutrinos. The Earth receives neutrino from many astrophysical objects, as well as from the early phases of the evolution of the universe. These neutrinos are very useful messengers, carrying information on several physical phenomena that take place in stars and in the universe.  The project has three main themes: neutrinos from collapsing stars (supernovae), cosmic high energy neutrinos from still mysterious astrophysical jets, and very low energy neutrinos from the early universe. 

On collapsing stars, extensive work was done to produce realistic, detailed predictions of the neutrino flux produced by a star in the days and hours before the star's core become unstable and collapses under its own weight. In a recent paper, it was shown that this pre-collapse neutrino flux is larger than previously expected, and could in principle be observed.  An observation would provide an early alert of the imminent collapse, and important information on the microphysical processes occuring in the very last phases of the star's evolution.  

On cosmic high energy neutrinos, a number of works were completed on understanding the data observed by the IceCube neutrino observatory. A paper was completed on the hypothesis that some of the observed neutrinos might be due to the Fermi Bubbles, two large structured of our galaxy that were discovered recently and are copious sources of gamma rays. In the paper, it was shown that important information on the Fermi Bubbles (whose origin is still not known) can be gained by combining the IceCube data with upcoming observations from the gamma ray telescope HAWC. A different line of investigation showed that some of the observed high energy neutrinos come from regions of the sky that are close, spatially, to sites where new stars are formed at a particularly high rate, thus suggesting that star formation might be related to the origin of these neutrinos. It was estimated that the these spatial associations between neutrinos and star formation are unlikely to be due to random coincidence.   

On the subject of neutrinos from the early universe, a study was done on how these neutrinos, which have never been observed so far, could possibly be detected via their capture on tritium nuclei. A paper was published on the potential of a new tritium-based apparatus that was proposed recently. The main finding is that results from this hypothetical experiment would be able to distinguish the fundamental nature of the neutrinos as particle, and in particular understand if the neutrinos are Majorana particles, which would make them fundamentally different from electrons and other known particles. 

Other results of this project are not mentioned here from brevity. This project involved students and postdoctoral researchers, all of whom are successfully continuing their career in science. These students, postdocs, as well as the faculty Principal Investigator, have presented the results of this project at conferences and other professional events, where they were well received.
